hashtag#hiring hashtag#immediatejoiners hashtag#GuidewireDeveloper hashtag#BusinessAnalystforGuidewire hashtag#QAAnalystforGuidewire hashtag#PolicyCenter hashtag#ClaimCenter hashtag#GosuScripting hashtag#Java hashtag#GuidewireStudio hashtag#WebServices hashtag#APIs hashtag#GuidewireCloud hashtag#GuidewireBillingCenter hashtag#Onsite hashtag#PanIndiaLocation hashtag#PanIndiajobs Hi, Greetings from Warrior Tech Solutions.Role:                   Business Analyst/QA Analyst for Guidewire, Guidewire DeveloperLocation:            Pan India (Onsite)Experience:        6+ years Notice:               Immediate to 15 daysJob Description:We are looking for highly skilled professionals with over six years of experience working with Guidewire Policy Center and Claim Center. This role involves designing, implementing, and optimizing Guidewire applications to support business operations and deliver high-quality results. Key Responsibilities:Design, develop, and implement solutions within Guidewire Policy Center and Claim Center.Configure and customize Guidewire applications to meet business requirements.Collaborate with business analysts, architects, and stakeholders to gather and refine system requirements.Lead integration efforts between Guidewire applications and third-party systems.Troubleshoot and resolve issues related to Guidewire applications, ensuring optimal system performance.Provide technical guidance and best practices for Guidewire implementation and maintenance.Participate in code reviews, testing, and quality assurance processes.Ensure compliance with industry standards and company policies.Train and mentor junior team members on Guidewire best practices. Required Skills & Qualifications:Minimum 6+ years of experience working with Guidewire Policy Center & Claim Center.Strong insurance industry knowledge, particularly in P&C insurance.Hands-on experience in Guidewire configuration, integration, and implementation.Proficiency in Gosu scripting, Java, and Guidewire Studio.Experience with Guidewire Data Model, Web Services, APIs, and Batch Processing.Knowledge of Guidewire Cloud and on-premises implementations.Strong analytical and problem-solving skills.Excellent communication and stakeholder management abilities. Preferred Qualifications:Guidewire Certification in Policy Center and/or Claim Center.Experience in Agile methodologies and DevOps practices.Exposure to Guidewire Billing Center is a plus.Experience in working with Guidewire Digital and portals.If interested, kindly share the resumes to *bharathi@ewarriorstechsolutions.com* or contact @8015568995.

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

hashtag#hiring hashtag#immediatejoiners hashtag#GuidewireDeveloper hashtag#BusinessAnalystforGuidewire hashtag#QAAnalystforGuidewire hashtag#PolicyCenter hashtag#ClaimCenter hashtag#GosuScripting hashtag#Java hashtag#GuidewireStudio hashtag#WebServices hashtag#APIs hashtag#GuidewireCloud hashtag#GuidewireBillingCenter hashtag#Onsite hashtag#PanIndiaLocation hashtag#PanIndiajobs Hi, Greetings from Warrior Tech Solutions.Role:                   Business Analyst/QA Analyst for Guidewire, Guidewire DeveloperLocation:            Pan India (Onsite)Experience:        6+ years Notice:               Immediate to 15 daysJob Description:We are looking for highly skilled professionals with over six years of experience working with Guidewire Policy Center and Claim Center. The ideal candidate will have a solid background in the insurance industry and strong technical expertise in Guidewire solutions. This role involves designing, implementing, and optimizing Guidewire applications to support business operations and deliver high-quality results. Key Responsibilities:Design, develop, and implement solutions within Guidewire Policy Center and Claim Center.Configure and customize Guidewire applications to meet business requirements.Collaborate with business analysts, architects, and stakeholders to gather and refine system requirements.Lead integration efforts between Guidewire applications and third-party systems.Troubleshoot and resolve issues related to Guidewire applications, ensuring optimal system performance.Provide technical guidance and best practices for Guidewire implementation and maintenance.Participate in code reviews, testing, and quality assurance processes.Ensure compliance with industry standards and company policies.Train and mentor junior team members on Guidewire best practices. Required Skills & Qualifications:Minimum 6+ years of experience working with Guidewire Policy Center & Claim Center.Strong insurance industry knowledge, particularly in P&C insurance.Hands-on experience in Guidewire configuration, integration, and implementation.Proficiency in Gosu scripting, Java, and Guidewire Studio.Experience with Guidewire Data Model, Web Services, APIs, and Batch Processing.Knowledge of Guidewire Cloud and on-premises implementations.Strong analytical and problem-solving skills.Excellent communication and stakeholder management abilities. Preferred Qualifications:Guidewire Certification in Policy Center and/or Claim Center.Experience in Agile methodologies and DevOps practices.Exposure to Guidewire Billing Center is a plus.Experience in working with Guidewire Digital and portals.If interested, kindly share the resumes to *bharathi@ewarriorstechsolutions.com* or contact @8015568995.

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

hashtag#hiring hashtag#immediatejoiners hashtag#GuidewireDeveloper hashtag#BusinessAnalystforGuidewire hashtag#QAAnalystforGuidewire hashtag#PolicyCenter hashtag#ClaimCenter hashtag#GosuScripting hashtag#Java hashtag#GuidewireStudio hashtag#WebServices hashtag#APIs hashtag#GuidewireCloud hashtag#GuidewireBillingCenter hashtag#Onsite hashtag#PanIndiaLocation hashtag#PanIndiajobs Hi, Greetings from Warrior Tech Solutions.Role:                   Business Analyst/QA Analyst for Guidewire, Guidewire DeveloperLocation:            Pan India (Onsite)Experience:        6+ years Notice:               Immediate to 15 daysJob Description:We are looking for highly skilled professionals with over six years of experience working with Guidewire Policy Center and Claim Center. The ideal candidate will have a solid background in the insurance industry and strong technical expertise in Guidewire solutions. This role involves designing, implementing, and optimizing Guidewire applications to support business operations and deliver high-quality results. Key Responsibilities:Design, develop, and implement solutions within Guidewire Policy Center and Claim Center.Configure and customize Guidewire applications to meet business requirements.Collaborate with business analysts, architects, and stakeholders to gather and refine system requirements.Lead integration efforts between Guidewire applications and third-party systems.Troubleshoot and resolve issues related to Guidewire applications, ensuring optimal system performance.Provide technical guidance and best practices for Guidewire implementation and maintenance.Participate in code reviews, testing, and quality assurance processes.Ensure compliance with industry standards and company policies.Train and mentor junior team members on Guidewire best practices. Required Skills & Qualifications:Minimum 6+ years of experience working with Guidewire Policy Center & Claim Center.Strong insurance industry knowledge, particularly in P&C insurance.Hands-on experience in Guidewire configuration, integration, and implementation.Proficiency in Gosu scripting, Java, and Guidewire Studio.Experience with Guidewire Data Model, Web Services, APIs, and Batch Processing.Knowledge of Guidewire Cloud and on-premises implementations.Strong analytical and problem-solving skills.Excellent communication and stakeholder management abilities. Preferred Qualifications:Guidewire Certification in Policy Center and/or Claim Center.Experience in Agile methodologies and DevOps practices.Exposure to Guidewire Billing Center is a plus.Experience in working with Guidewire Digital and portals.If interested, kindly share the resumes to *bharathi@ewarriorstechsolutions.com* or contact @8015568995.

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

hashtag#hiring hashtag#immediatejoiners hashtag#GuidewireDeveloper hashtag#BusinessAnalystforGuidewire hashtag#QAAnalystforGuidewire hashtag#PolicyCenter hashtag#ClaimCenter hashtag#GosuScripting hashtag#Java hashtag#GuidewireStudio hashtag#WebServices hashtag#APIs hashtag#GuidewireCloud hashtag#GuidewireBillingCenter hashtag#Onsite hashtag#PanIndiaLocation hashtag#PanIndiajobs Hi, Greetings from Warrior Tech Solutions.Role:                   Business Analyst/QA Analyst for Guidewire, Guidewire DeveloperLocation:            Pan India (Onsite)Experience:        6+ years Notice:               Immediate to 15 daysJob Description:We are looking for highly skilled professionals with over six years of experience working with Guidewire Policy Center and Claim Center. The ideal candidate will have a solid background in the insurance industry and strong technical expertise in Guidewire solutions. This role involves designing, implementing, and optimizing Guidewire applications to support business operations and deliver high-quality results. Key Responsibilities:Design, develop, and implement solutions within Guidewire Policy Center and Claim Center.Configure and customize Guidewire applications to meet business requirements.Collaborate with business analysts, architects, and stakeholders to gather and refine system requirements.Lead integration efforts between Guidewire applications and third-party systems.Troubleshoot and resolve issues related to Guidewire applications, ensuring optimal system performance.Provide technical guidance and best practices for Guidewire implementation and maintenance.Participate in code reviews, testing, and quality assurance processes.Ensure compliance with industry standards and company policies.Train and mentor junior team members on Guidewire best practices. Required Skills & Qualifications:Minimum 6+ years of experience working with Guidewire Policy Center & Claim Center.Strong insurance industry knowledge, particularly in P&C insurance.Hands-on experience in Guidewire configuration, integration, and implementation.Proficiency in Gosu scripting, Java, and Guidewire Studio.Experience with Guidewire Data Model, Web Services, APIs, and Batch Processing.Knowledge of Guidewire Cloud and on-premises implementations.Strong analytical and problem-solving skills.Excellent communication and stakeholder management abilities. Preferred Qualifications:Guidewire Certification in Policy Center and/or Claim Center.Experience in Agile methodologies and DevOps practices.Exposure to Guidewire Billing Center is a plus.Experience in working with Guidewire Digital and portals.If interested, kindly share the resumes to *bharathi@ewarriorstechsolutions.com* or contact @8015568995.

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

Costly and slow.The smarter approach? Many IT firms are outsourcing automation talent while keeping core manual testers in-house.This model offers scalability, flexibility, and cost efficiency—without long hiring cycles.How is your QA hiring strategy evolving? I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

hashtag#hiring hashtag#immediatejoiners hashtag#GuidewireDeveloper hashtag#BusinessAnalystforGuidewire hashtag#QAAnalystforGuidewire hashtag#PolicyCenter hashtag#ClaimCenter hashtag#GosuScripting hashtag#Java hashtag#GuidewireStudio hashtag#WebServices hashtag#APIs hashtag#GuidewireCloud hashtag#GuidewireBillingCenter hashtag#Onsite hashtag#PanIndiaLocation hashtag#PanIndiajobs Hi, Greetings from Warrior Tech Solutions.Role:                   Business Analyst/QA Analyst for Guidewire, Guidewire DeveloperLocation:            Pan India (Onsite)Experience:        6+ years Notice:               Immediate to 15 daysJob Description:We are looking for highly skilled professionals with over six years of experience working with Guidewire Policy Center and Claim Center. The ideal candidate will have a solid background in the insurance industry and strong technical expertise in Guidewire solutions. This role involves designing, implementing, and optimizing Guidewire applications to support business operations and deliver high-quality results. I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

hashtag#hiring hashtag#immediatejoiners hashtag#GuidewireDeveloper hashtag#BusinessAnalystforGuidewire hashtag#QAAnalystforGuidewire hashtag#PolicyCenter hashtag#ClaimCenter hashtag#GosuScripting hashtag#Java hashtag#GuidewireStudio hashtag#WebServices hashtag#APIs hashtag#GuidewireCloud hashtag#GuidewireBillingCenter hashtag#Onsite hashtag#PanIndiaLocation hashtag#PanIndiajobs Hi, Greetings from Warrior Tech Solutions.Role:                   Business Analyst/QA Analyst for Guidewire, Guidewire DeveloperLocation:            Pan India (Onsite)Experience:        6+ years Notice:               Immediate to 15 daysJob Description:We are looking for highly skilled professionals with over six years of experience working with Guidewire Policy Center and Claim Center. The ideal candidate will have a solid background in the insurance industry and strong technical expertise in Guidewire solutions. This role involves designing, implementing, and optimizing Guidewire applications to support business operations and deliver high-quality results. I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

I can’t believe the strategy of this game development company🤯Gaming is a billion-dollar industry, but hype alone doesn’t build success. Here’s a deep dive into how a development studio went from massive investment to tough layoffs👇It was set out to create a "Made-in-India" battle royale with global ambitions. The vision was strong, but the execution? Not so much.💰$10M+ invested, but a significant portion went into marketing, branding, and partnerships rather than actual game development.⚡Marketing Blitz – The company spent over ₹25L for Instagram promotions. Massive social media campaigns and influencer collaborations to built hype. 🤑 Expensive hiring practices – Offering ₹12LPA to fresh graduates when they could have hired more experienced developers for the same budget. →This led to talent gaps in crucial areas like game mechanics, optimization, and server stability.The project wasn’t just about making a great game—it became more about selling the dream. But when it came time to deliver, cracks started showing.🔹Marketing over Game Development – Instead of investing in refining gameplay and ensuring a polished experience, more focus was put on social media buzz, influencer partnerships, and PR stunts. 🔹High burn rate – The company overspent on branding, PR, and flashy hires, leading to unsustainable operations. 🔹No strategic execution – A strong brand can’t carry a weak product. They miscalculated their revenue model and struggled. Without a strong retention strategy, even the best marketing can’t save a game.When revenue didn’t meet expectations, the studio had to make difficult choices to survive:📉 One-third of the workforce laid off – Around 45 employees have already been let go65555. Entire teams, including the entire QA department, were reportedly dismissed.💸 Restructuring to cut losses – The leadership admitted they "miscalculated" and had to restructure teams to focus on core priorities.💔 Employee morale & community trust shaken – Layoffs always hurt, but when they follow high spending and poor planning, they leave a bigger impact on the studio’s reputation, employee trust, and community perception.Being a co-founder of a esports organization, I can hardly see why we should invest in Indus Esports scenario: ✅ Build first, promote later. Hype doesn’t fix a weak product. Focus on gameplay, user experience, and core mechanics before investing heavily in marketing.✅ Invest wisely, not blindly – A balanced budget across development, marketing, and retention is crucial. Bad marketing investments drain resources. ✅ Right people doing market research result in Better decisions – Having strong market research teams and decision-makers can prevent expensive mistakes and ensure a game’s success.The gaming industry is unforgiving—mistakes are costly, and only those who adapt and prioritize player experience survive. 🎮The real question is, can *Super Gaming’s Indus Battle Royale* bounce back? 🤔

Familiarity with version control systems like Git and deployment tools like Jenkins. Strong understanding of SFRA (Storefront Reference Architecture). Knowledge of performance optimization and caching strategies. Good understanding of CI/CD and agile methodologies. Salesforce B2C Commerce Developer certification is a plus.  Nice to Have: Experience working with headless commerce or PWA integrations. Exposure to other Salesforce clouds (e.g., SFMC, Service Cloud) is a bonus.
